Title: New Analysis Finds Trump Family Has Raked in $3.4 Billion Off the Presidency
Description:
By 

	Nikki McCann Ramirez



	Even before Donald Trump officially began his second term in office, his family businesses were beginning the race to milk the presidency for every cent they could. Now, a new analysis from The New Yorker has put a potential dollar figure on how much Trump's crypto ventures, real estate deals, licensing agreements, and other grifts have netted America's first family over the course of Trump's time in politics: a staggering $3.4 billion.


	The total is an estimate, as the Trump Organization and its various auxiliary companies and ventures — which are largely under the control of the president's adult children — have not been entirely transparent regarding their finances.


The New Yorker estimated that the president's various cryptocurrency had generated at least $2.37 billion in value, financial investments coordinated by Donald Jr. and Eric Trump have generated $339.6 million, and Trump's flagship Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida, has raked in $125 million in extra profits.

	











	Tack onto that $127.7 million in legal fee collection and merchandise sales and a media empire estimated to be worth $116 million, and it becomes clear that the Trumps have built themselves a corporate empire on the back of their patriarch's public office. 




			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	Just last month, the president took a detour from a state trip to Scotland, for which millions of taxpayer dollars were spent on travel and security, to inaugurate a new Trump golf course near Aberdeen, Scotland. On that same trip, Trump hosted British Prime Minister Keir Starmer at his private Turnberry golf club — which (as was the practice during Trump's first term) will likely profit off of the president's choice to use it as a venue. The same week, it was reported that Trump has privately discussed hosting the G20 summit of world leaders at his Doral golf club.

	











	As previously reported by Rolling Stone, the president has complained to his inner circle that it was “stupid” of him to leave so much money on the table during his first term, and that he planned to rectify his mistake the second time around.





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Announces New Album 'The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Curates Spotify Playlist Ahead of New LP ‘The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Meet CORTIS, the Coolest K-Pop Debut of the Year		
	









	
	
		
					Grok Claims It Was Briefly Suspended From X After Accusing Israel of Genocide		
	









	The fact that the family's business deals making headlines around the world are being coordinated by Trump's children is a convenient loophole that allows the president to escape many of the disclosure and ethics laws that govern private investments by public officials.


	After years accusing his political opponents — and their sons — of leveraging the status of the White House to enrich themselves, the Trumps are engaged in an open campaign of open grift unlike any in the history of the Oval Office, and Americans are now just beginning to get a full picture of just how rich the People's House is making the president.

Title: Jimmy Kimmel Says He Obtained Italian Citizenship to Flee 'Unbelievably' Bad Trump Administration
Description:
By 

	Andre Gee



Jimmy Kimmel‘s dislike of President Donald Trump seems to have reached an inflection point. The late-night host has felt so dismayed by the administration's fascist policies that he's set up a bit of a contingency plan to flee the country altogether if need be. During a recent appearance on The Sarah Silverman podcast, Kimmel informed his ex and fellow comedian that an intercontinental move may be in store after he obtained his Italian citizenship.


	“A lot of people I know are thinking about where are they going to get citizenship?” Silverman said. Kimmel replied, “I did get Italian citizenship,” noting, “What's going on [with Trump] is as bad as you thought it was gonna be. It's so much worse; it's just unbelievable. I feel like it's probably even worse than he would like it to be.”





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Announces New Album 'The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Curates Spotify Playlist Ahead of New LP ‘The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Meet CORTIS, the Coolest K-Pop Debut of the Year		
	









	
	
		
					Grok Claims It Was Briefly Suspended From X After Accusing Israel of Genocide		
	









	Kimmel has been a vocal detractor of Trump during both of his terms. Following Trump's first 100 days in office, the comedian dedicated an opening monologue on his show to roasting the inefficiency of the government. “It's difficult to give Trump's first 100 days a grade, but if I had to I'd say it falls somewhere between F and U,” he said. “Don't get me wrong, there have been some positives. Unfortunately, they have all been pregnancy tests for women who slept with Elon Musk.” Noting how little Trump got done, he said, “None of those achievements are achievements,” he said. “The penny is gone and straws are back. Wow, America really is great again, isn't it? This tells you all you need to know about how things are going for Trump.”

	











	If Kimmel leaves the United States, he would join Rosie O'Donnell and Ellen DeGeneres as celebrities who fled the United States after Trump defeated Vice President Kamala Harris in last November's presidential election.

Title: Mayday Parade Is Ready for a ‘Sad' Fall
Description:
By 

	Maya Georgi



	Sweater weather is coming — and so is another Mayday Parade release. The pop-punkers have announced, Sad, the second installment of their 20th anniversary album trilogy, out Oct. 3. The band also shared reflective rocker, “Under My Sweater,” alongside a new music video.


	“It's difficult to sing about a sweater without invoking Weezer, but that's part of what I love about this song,” Derek Sanders said in a statement. With its melancholy riffs and Nineties-inspired percussion, Sanders described the song as “a part of old school nostalgic emo” but with a modern twist.


Sad comes on the heels of the band's first release of the three-part album, Sweet, which arrived in April. As the title suggests, this new installment serves as a counterpart to its predecessor with a softer, more introspective mood compared to the anthemic pop-punk vitality of Sweet. It seems especially fitting for the forthcoming fall season. Even with its contrasting sound, Sad brings back producers Zack Odom and Kenneth Mount into the fold.

	











	Though a track list for Sad has yet to be released, a press release promises heartbreak, ballads, and loads of fall-time, Nineties nostalgia for songs like “Promises,” “One Day At a Time,” and “I Miss the 90s.” Album closer “I Must Obey The Inscrutable Exhortations Of My Soul” brings back Mayday Parade's penchant for long, emo-inspired song titles and is set to be the band's “most ambitious recording to date.”

	











	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Announces New Album 'The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Curates Spotify Playlist Ahead of New LP ‘The Life of a Showgirl'		
	









	
	
		
					Meet CORTIS, the Coolest K-Pop Debut of the Year		
	









	
	
		
					Grok Claims It Was Briefly Suspended From X After Accusing Israel of Genocide		
	








			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	The release of Sweet and Sad coincides with the start of Mayday Parade's 20th anniversary tour, where the band will revisit their entire discography across several U.S. cities and celebrate their two decades together.


	In an interview with Rolling Stone earlier this year, the band revealed how the unconventional album trilogy idea came to be. As Mayday Parade went into the studio to record their first LP since 2021's What It Means to Fall Apart, Sanders realized their 20th anniversary was coming up, and it inspired the band to change course. “We just thought, ‘What if we tried to do something bigger and more grand?'” he said, adding, “It's kind of an experiment and feels like the right time to try something like this.”

Title: UFO's spotted over Gosport
Description:
Tuesday, 12 August 2025 08:00
                


                        By Philip Keeler
                                                    

X

                                @keeler_philip
                            



            A late-night dog walk in Gosport has turned into something rather more unusual for one local resident, who claims to have spotted not one but two unidentified flying objects in the early hours of Tuesday 9th July 2025.
        

According to a report submitted to the National UFO Reporting Centre (NUFORC) website, the incident occurred at around 1:15am. The witness, whose name has not been released, described seeing two bright, star-like objects high in the sky. Initially motionless, the lights suddenly began moving rapidly toward each other. Rather than colliding, they reportedly circled one another for a short period before abruptly accelerating away in opposite directions.

The sighting, the report says, lasted for approximately five minutes before the objects disappeared from view.

The National UFO Reporting Centre, based in the United States, collects eyewitness accounts from around the world. Although most sightings turn out to have conventional explanations — such as satellites, drones, aircraft lights, or astronomical phenomena — some reports remain unexplained after investigation. This Gosport case has yet to be analysed in detail.

The timing of the sighting comes amid growing global fascination with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAPs) — the term now preferred by governments and defence agencies for what the public traditionally calls UFOs. In recent years, the US Congress has held hearings on the subject, prompted in part by declassified US Navy videos showing fast-moving airborne objects that military pilots could not identify.

Such high-profile discussions have led to a surge in public interest, with more people coming forward to share their own observations of strange lights and objects in the sky. Reports have been logged from countries across the globe, with patterns often emerging during warm, clear weather when more people are outdoors at night.

Whether the Gosport sighting turns out to be an example of advanced human-made technology, an atmospheric illusion, or something altogether more mysterious, it joins a growing catalogue of eyewitness accounts feeding the ongoing debate about what might be out there.

For now, the dog walker's account stands as another entry in NUFORC's long-running database — a reminder that, even on an ordinary night walk, the skies can sometimes hold extraordinary surprises.

Is the truth out there? Have you seen strange lights and objects in the sky? do you have images and video? Get in touch news@v2radio.co.uk

                    Hampshire County Council will dish out more than £190,000 in grants to provide extra wraparound care for primary school pupils.
                


                    Plans for a new secondary school in Burgess Hill have been put on hold amid falling demand for places.
                


                    A state-of-the-art Acute Stroke Centre is on track to open at St Richard's Hospital in Chichester by 2027.
                


                    A man from Albania has been arrested at an immigration detention centre near Gatwick Airport as part of a National Crime Agency investigation into organised immigration crime.

Title: Is Mothman in Pa.? ‘It's probably much weirder we think it is'
Description:
Editor's note: Welcome to the world of “Paranormal PA,” a PennLive series that delves into Pennsylvania-grown stories of spirits; cryptids; oddities and legends; and the unexplained. Sign up here to get our Paranormal PA newsletter delivered to your inbox.

Many a comparison can be drawn between your average classic rock star and the Mothman. 

He's mysterious. A bit of a loner. Came up in the sixties. And has a dedicated fanbase that's spawned conventions and a series of erotica. 

But while Mothman is undoubtedly the cryptid of West Virginia, the reach and sightings of this red-eye, winged, moth-like humanoid have expanded beyond the Mountain State and into places like Pennsylvania.

In “John A. Keel: The Man, the Myths, and the Ongoing Mysteries (2019),” Greensburg-based paranormal researcher Stan Gordon tells author Brent Raynes that the first time Mothman popped up in Pennsylvania was in the summer of 1966, in a wooded part of Allegheny County, right near Pittsburgh.

As Gordon tells it, a young man was shaken up after a “strange creature leaped onto the back of his black convertible.” The young man gunned it, terrified, causing the thing to fall off his car, leaving “streaks of a white, juicy substance on the back of the vehicle.” Teenagers began to report creepy encounters with a tall, winged creature in the woods; UFO activity was even reported in the area around the same time. 

And the sightings didn't stop then, either. The York Daily Record mentions a few reports in Adams County in the 1980s and a video of a purported Mothman sighting in Monroeville circulated on the Internet in 2017. Tobias Wayland, co-author of “Mothman: Sightings and Investigations of Iconic Flying Cryptid (2025),” tells Paranormal PA via email he even got a report from a person in Levittown several years ago “who said they saw something that ‘had the body of a human, but it had wings,' climb over their fence and crawl towards them before emitting a terrifying scream and flying away.”

Now, eagle-eyed Mothman aficionados might recognize 1966 as the year of the first official Mothman sighting took place. In fact, Gordon's account places the Mothman sightings in Pennsylvania as having happened before the most famous sighting in West Virginia.

That was on a fateful night in November of that year. “Mothman: The Facts Behind the Legend (2002)” reports that two couples — the Scarberrys and the Mallettes — spotted what a Point Pleasant Register article then called a “man-sized bird … creature … something!” near the McClintic Wildlife Station in Point Pleasant, West Virginia. 

“They told a deputy sheriff it looked like ‘a flying man with 10-foot wings,'” the Kalamazoo Gazette later reported. “They said it was about seven feet tall with large red eyes.”

The Gazette explained that the story had drawn curious onlookers to the site, and, for about three days afterward, at least eight other people reported seeing the same creature. The name “Mothman” didn't take too long to start popping up in coverage.

But what was Mothman? Well, the Springfield Daily News proclaimed “W. Virginia Mothman Not From Outer Space,” weeding at least one theory out (although theories about Mothman's extraterrestrial origins persist). 

Some speculated he was a supernatural entity, while John Keel put forward the idea in his 1975 book “Mothman Prophecies” that Mothman was “Ultraterrestrial,” or an ancient hidden race of beings that that have lived beside us in secret. Others said it was probably just a big bird. 

“The phenomenon currently defies easy explanation,” wrote Richard Estep, the other co-author of “Mothman,” to Paranormal PA via email. “We couldn't nail that answer down in 70,000 words.

“I think it's one aspect of a multi-faceted phenomenon that manifests in different ways at different times for people, and is part of the flying humanoid subset of anomalies. What I can say with confidence is that it's probably much weirder than we think it is.”

Whatever he was (or is), the initial madness of the Mothman story eventually died down. According to the Gazette, it seemed like the excitement over the whole thing had at last fizzled out as the fad it was after a few weeks.

But here we are, almost 60 years later, and the Mothman legend has continued to live — vivaciously almost, despite the fact he supposedly serves as a bad omen. There's an annual festival, books, merchandise, and a 2002 adaptation of the classic John Keel book, “The Mothman Prophecies,” starring Richard Gere and Laura Linney (and which, it just so happens, was filmed in Pittsburgh).

So what is it that makes the Mothman legend so popular outside of its West Virginia roots, especially considering there are plenty of other localized legends that don't nearly have as big a fanbase (see the squonk)? In fact, why are people so enamored with cryptozoology in general, when practically all of modern science points to the unlikelihood in the existence of creatures like Bigfoot or Raystown Ray?

According to Estep and Wayland, it's not that Mr. Mothman has some sort of je nais se quoi, but, rather the fact that creature sightings were brought up in national news each time a disaster such as a bridge collapse occurred. That, and the film adaptation brought the legend to a wider audience.

“I think Mothman speaks to us on a very deep level,” Wayland said. “The amount of strange phenomena associated with the mystery — everything from UFOs to hauntings to Mothman's uncanny nature — speak to a hidden reality that people find compelling.

“The world is a terrifying place that isn't made less so by understanding it, but perhaps in attempting to understand high strangeness, we can find an escape from it; either metaphorically, in the same way we escape into a movie or book, or literally, in the sense that if there is some invisible world inhabited by such beings, maybe we'd rather live there then here.”

However, out of all the supernatural phenomenon that people believe in, many skeptics raise their eyebrows particularly high when it comes to cryptozoology: Wouldn't scientists have discovered a Bigfoot-like species by now, skeptics ask? Wouldn't modern-day cameras and other technology have captured proof of Nessie?

Well, similar to other legends — like that pair of tombstones in Pennsylvania that's believed to bring about the end of the world — Wayland explains that cryptid legends “speak to different anxieties.” Specifically, ennui. 

“Cryptids are about our fear that there's nothing new to discover in the world,” Wayland says. 

Whether or not Mothman is a symbol of a deeper fear — or just a fun story to partake in — he remains high on the totem pole of American legends. You can even get into him. yourself, if you want: There's that festival, a Mothman 5K, and a plethora of media you can consume, from books to video games.

As for the Mothman erotica ... you can look that up in your own time.

Title: A New Paranormal Comedy From ‘Rick and Morty' Writer Matt Roller Is Coming to Netflix Next Month
Description:
In addition to ‘Rick and Morty', Roller has also written for ‘Community', ‘Speechless', ‘Son of Zorn', and ‘Archer'.

Netflix will soon have a new show for “fans of comedy, horror, horror comedy, families, hotels, cults, monsters with tentacles, monsters without tentacles, werewolves, and blenders.” That's according to Matt Roller, Rick and Morty writer and creator of Haunted Hotel, a new paranormal comedy heading to Netflix next month.

Haunted Hotel will follow a single mother of two who struggles to run a haunted hotel. She receives some help from her estranged brother, who is now one of the ghosts haunting the hotel. The first season will have 10 episodes.

The main cast will be voiced by Will Forte, Eliza Coupe, Skyler Gisondo, Natalie Palamides, and Jimmi Simpson. 

Netflix's Director of Adult Animation, Billy Wee, said “Haunted Hotel is wildly inventive and I'm very grateful to Matt, Chris, Dan, and their team for bringing their talents to Netflix…They are phenomenal collaborators and I can't wait for fans all over the world to experience this hilarious show.”

Haunted Hotel will premiere on Netflix on September 19.

Meet The Author

Chrissy is the co-founder of Creepy Catalog. She has over 10 years of experience writing about horror, a degree in philosophy and Reiki level II certification.

Title: MGK thinks he's part alien, reveals mother was previously abducted by space beings
Description:
"I'm bad at talking," the rapper said on "Watch What Happens Live" with Andy Cohen. "I shouldn't have came on a talk show."

Theo Wargo/NBC via Getty; Getty

 Recording artist MGK — formerly known as Machine Gun Kelly — does not think he's from the earthly realm, according to himself (and his alleged interplanetary bloodline).


 During a Sunday night appearance on Andy Cohen's Bravo talk show Watch What Happens Live, the rapper (previously reported to be 35 years old, but now TBD) responded to a question about his age in a state of confusion.


 "It's a weird thing, dude, I don't know if my age... I don't know if it exists," he said.


 Christopher Polk/Billboard via Getty

 Cohen asked, "You have a Mariah Carey connection to your age? It's very fluid?" with reference to Carey's admitted refusal to acknowledge time.


 "I don't know many facts about my life, so I don't know," MGK responded. "I'm starting to be like, if my skin rips open, it heals really quick. I'm starting to be like, who's my dad?"


 Cohen pressed on, asking, "Do you think you could be otherworldly?" to which MGK responded, "I asked my mom, is there any period of time you went missing? A tall, slender creature?"


 Fellow WWHL guest Pamela Adlon quipped, "That tracks," before MGK continued.


 "She told me she felt like she got abducted at one point," recalled MGK. "I'm bad at talking, I shouldn't have came on a talk show."


 Entertainment Weekly has reached out to a representative for MGK for additional information on his suspected alien heritage.


 Perhaps MGK is who The View moderator Whoopi Goldberg warned her cohosts about in March 2024, when she confirmed live on the air that aliens are, in fact, walking among us on earth.


 "I think they're waiting for us to clean up a little bit so that they can come here and tell us we're really messing things up," View guest Kumail Nanjiani joked about alien beings, before Goldberg responded in earnest with her findings about extraterrestrial existence.


 "They're already here," she said, calmly. "They're already ... They've been here for quite some time."


 A stunned Nanjiani turned to Goldberg for more information, as the Ghost actress did not reveal how — or why — she knew of her findings that she brought to the Hot Topics table.


 Sign up for Entertainment Weekly's free daily newsletter to get breaking news, exclusive first looks, recaps, reviews, interviews with your favorite stars, and more.


 "And what are they doing?" he asked, to which she responded: "They're watching us." Or, perhaps they're simply singing the 2016 song "Bad Things" (feat. Camilla Cabello).


 Watch MGK discuss his alien roots on Watch What Happens Live above.

Title: Why Machine Gun Kelly Thinks He's Part-Alien
Description:
Photo: Getty Images

Machine Gun Kelly thinks he might be part-alien. 

The Tickets to My Downfall hitmaker appeared on the August 10 episode of Watch What Happens Live With Andy Cohen and explained why he thinks he's extraterrestrial. 

"It's a weird thing, dude," he began, "I don't know if my age...I don't know if it exists."

The standout, born Colson Baker, who shares 4-month-old Saga Blade with ex Megan Fox and 16-year-old Casie with ex Emma Cannon, revealed that he doesn't know a few key details about his life, like his real age and who his father is. 

"I just don't know many facts about my life. Like my skin, if it rips open, it heals really quick. There's just things where I'm starting to be like, ‘Who's my dad?'"

Kelly's mother has even admitted that, at one point in her life, she feels like she might have been abducted. 

"Yeah, I've asked my mom. Was there any period of time you went missing, like off the Earth? Was there ever like a tall slender creature?' She told me she felt like she got abducted at one point."

For more from the interview, read Machine Gun Kelly Finally Addresses Sydney Sweeney Dating Rumors.

Title: Jared Padalecki Reveals 1 Supernatural Relationship He Wishes Didn't Happen
Description:
Jared Padalecki revealed the one Supernatural relationship that he wishes had not happened. Over the 15 seasons that Supernatural aired, Sam and Dean Winchester had many different relationships, especially Dean, who was a notorious womanizer. However, rather interestingly, despite being the “ladies man” of the CW show, Dean actually had fewer love interests than Sam.

Although Supernatural ended in 2020, fans and stars of the show are still reflecting on its legacy, with Jensen Ackles (Dean) and Jared Padalecki (Sam) attending various fan conventions around the world. One of the things that was recently discussed was their characters' decisions in the show, which brought up an interesting comment from Padalecki about Sam Winchester's love interests.

At a FAN EXPO Boston panel, in which ScreenRant was in attendance, Padalecki was asked if Sam would make any decisions differently now. Padalecki responded that he doesn't think Sam would have gotten into a relationship with Amelia. He also expressed that he wished Sam had looked harder for Dean when he was in Purgatory. Check out his quote below:

Amelia. I don't think he would've gotten into a romantic relationship after his brother… over a dog, yeah.

 Amelia Richardson (Liane Balaban) was a veterinarian introduced in season 8. She became a love interest of Sam's while Dean was missing and presumed dead in Purgatory. The two formed an unlikely bond after Sam accidentally hit a dog with his car, leading to a quiet suburban storyline that was somewhat disconnected from the show's supernatural drama.

Padalecki's comment seems to suggest that he agrees with some of the fan criticism surrounding Amelia, which states that the relationship felt forced and Sam's lack of focus on finding his missing brother felt out of sync with the Winchesters' usual actions. The “over a dog” remark only highlights how Padalecki seemingly felt the relationship was a bit too convenient.

 While there was nothing particularly wrong with Amelia's character, the whole romantic plotline with Sam did feel strangely out of place at the time. Amelia was an interesting addition in season 8, as she brought a complicated relationship with her presumed-dead husband, who eventually returns. Interestingly, she is also one of Supernatural's few major love interest characters who doesn't die.

Yet, as Dean and Castiel vanished into Purgatory after fighting Dick Roman and the Leviathans, one of Supernatural's most powerful creatures, it wasn't the right time for Sam's romantic subplot. It was almost too obviously a mirror of Dean's relationship with Lisa when Sam was presumed dead in Supernatural season 6, and for that reason, Padalecki's comments are justified.

Supernatural is a television series that follows brothers Sam and Dean Winchester, who were raised by their father to hunt and combat supernatural entities after losing their mother to a demonic force. Traversing the American landscape in their '67 Chevy Impala, they face numerous paranormal threats.

Title: Is Mothman in Pa.? ‘It's probably much weirder we think it is'
Description:
Editor's note: Welcome to the world of “Paranormal PA,” a PennLive series that delves into Pennsylvania-grown stories of spirits; cryptids; oddities and legends; and the unexplained. Sign up here to get our Paranormal PA newsletter delivered to your inbox.

Many a comparison can be drawn between your average classic rock star and the Mothman. 

He's mysterious. A bit of a loner. Came up in the sixties. And has a dedicated fanbase that's spawned conventions and a series of erotica. 

But while Mothman is undoubtedly the cryptid of West Virginia, the reach and sightings of this red-eye, winged, moth-like humanoid have expanded beyond the Mountain State and into places like Pennsylvania.

In “John A. Keel: The Man, the Myths, and the Ongoing Mysteries (2019),” Greensburg-based paranormal researcher Stan Gordon tells author Brent Raynes that the first time Mothman popped up in Pennsylvania was in the summer of 1966, in a wooded part of Allegheny County, right near Pittsburgh.

As Gordon tells it, a young man was shaken up after a “strange creature leaped onto the back of his black convertible.” The young man gunned it, terrified, causing the thing to fall off his car, leaving “streaks of a white, juicy substance on the back of the vehicle.” Teenagers began to report creepy encounters with a tall, winged creature in the woods; UFO activity was even reported in the area around the same time. 

And the sightings didn't stop then, either. The York Daily Record mentions a few reports in Adams County in the 1980s and a video of a purported Mothman sighting in Monroeville circulated on the Internet in 2017. Tobias Wayland, co-author of “Mothman: Sightings and Investigations of Iconic Flying Cryptid (2025),” tells Paranormal PA via email he even got a report from a person in Levittown several years ago “who said they saw something that ‘had the body of a human, but it had wings,' climb over their fence and crawl towards them before emitting a terrifying scream and flying away.”

Now, eagle-eyed Mothman aficionados might recognize 1966 as the year of the first official Mothman sighting took place. In fact, Gordon's account places the Mothman sightings in Pennsylvania as having happened before the most famous sighting in West Virginia.

That was on a fateful night in November of that year. “Mothman: The Facts Behind the Legend (2002)” reports that two couples — the Scarberrys and the Mallettes — spotted what a Point Pleasant Register article then called a “man-sized bird … creature … something!” near the McClintic Wildlife Station in Point Pleasant, West Virginia. 

“They told a deputy sheriff it looked like ‘a flying man with 10-foot wings,'” the Kalamazoo Gazette later reported. “They said it was about seven feet tall with large red eyes.”

The Gazette explained that the story had drawn curious onlookers to the site, and, for about three days afterward, at least eight other people reported seeing the same creature. The name “Mothman” didn't take too long to start popping up in coverage.

But what was Mothman? Well, the Springfield Daily News proclaimed “W. Virginia Mothman Not From Outer Space,” weeding at least one theory out (although theories about Mothman's extraterrestrial origins persist). 

Some speculated he was a supernatural entity, while John Keel put forward the idea in his 1975 book “Mothman Prophecies” that Mothman was “Ultraterrestrial,” or an ancient hidden race of beings that that have lived beside us in secret. Others said it was probably just a big bird. 

“The phenomenon currently defies easy explanation,” wrote Richard Estep, the other co-author of “Mothman,” to Paranormal PA via email. “We couldn't nail that answer down in 70,000 words.

“I think it's one aspect of a multi-faceted phenomenon that manifests in different ways at different times for people, and is part of the flying humanoid subset of anomalies. What I can say with confidence is that it's probably much weirder than we think it is.”

Whatever he was (or is), the initial madness of the Mothman story eventually died down. According to the Gazette, it seemed like the excitement over the whole thing had at last fizzled out as the fad it was after a few weeks.

But here we are, almost 60 years later, and the Mothman legend has continued to live — vivaciously almost, despite the fact he supposedly serves as a bad omen. There's an annual festival, books, merchandise, and a 2002 adaptation of the classic John Keel book, “The Mothman Prophecies,” starring Richard Gere and Laura Linney (and which, it just so happens, was filmed in Pittsburgh).

So what is it that makes the Mothman legend so popular outside of its West Virginia roots, especially considering there are plenty of other localized legends that don't nearly have as big a fanbase (see the squonk)? In fact, why are people so enamored with cryptozoology in general, when practically all of modern science points to the unlikelihood in the existence of creatures like Bigfoot or Raystown Ray?

According to Estep and Wayland, it's not that Mr. Mothman has some sort of je nais se quoi, but, rather the fact that creature sightings were brought up in national news each time a disaster such as a bridge collapse occurred. That, and the film adaptation brought the legend to a wider audience.

“I think Mothman speaks to us on a very deep level,” Wayland said. “The amount of strange phenomena associated with the mystery — everything from UFOs to hauntings to Mothman's uncanny nature — speak to a hidden reality that people find compelling.

“The world is a terrifying place that isn't made less so by understanding it, but perhaps in attempting to understand high strangeness, we can find an escape from it; either metaphorically, in the same way we escape into a movie or book, or literally, in the sense that if there is some invisible world inhabited by such beings, maybe we'd rather live there then here.”

However, out of all the supernatural phenomenon that people believe in, many skeptics raise their eyebrows particularly high when it comes to cryptozoology: Wouldn't scientists have discovered a Bigfoot-like species by now, skeptics ask? Wouldn't modern-day cameras and other technology have captured proof of Nessie?

Well, similar to other legends — like that pair of tombstones in Pennsylvania that's believed to bring about the end of the world — Wayland explains that cryptid legends “speak to different anxieties.” Specifically, ennui. 

“Cryptids are about our fear that there's nothing new to discover in the world,” Wayland says. 

Whether or not Mothman is a symbol of a deeper fear — or just a fun story to partake in — he remains high on the totem pole of American legends. You can even get into him. yourself, if you want: There's that festival, a Mothman 5K, and a plethora of media you can consume, from books to video games.

As for the Mothman erotica ... you can look that up in your own time.

Title: Solve the Unsolvable with these 7 Must-Listen Audiobooks About Psychic Detectives
Description:
If you love your mysteries with a touch of the supernatural, then this list is for you. Psychic detective stories bring an eerie twist to crime-solving, blending intuitive insight with spine-chilling suspense. These protagonists aren't just reading clues, they're reading minds, seeing visions and stepping into the unknown to crack cases that leave ordinary investigators stumped. Whether you enjoy dark thrillers, quirky paranormals or deeply emotional psychological mysteries, these audiobooks deliver suspenseful stories packed with psychic sleuthing.

So, plug in your headphones, close your eyes (unless you're driving, of course) and get ready for a binge-worthy lineup of gripping audiobooks that'll keep you guessing until the last second.

Performed by Joshua Jackson, Oracle is a psychological thriller that introduces Nate Russo, an FBI psychic with a disturbing ability. When he touches someone close to a victim, he sees the terrifying moments leading up to their disappearance. It's a gift that comes at a terrible cost, eating away at Russo's mind as he's pulled into a complex investigation involving missing girls, a chilling conspiracy and a darkness that may consume him. Pyper's writing is razor-sharp and atmospheric and Jackson's performance adds a grounded, emotional intensity to this tense, haunting narrative. Perfect for listeners who want the psychological weight of Mindhunter with a paranormal twist.

While Amos Decker isn't a psychic, his mind works in ways that are just as intriguing. After a devastating hit on the football field, he developed hyperthymesia and synesthesia, which means he forgets nothing and experiences memories through vivid colors and textures. This uncanny mental landscape makes him a formidable detective, especially when a shocking massacre strikes close to home. Memory Man launches Baldacci's bestselling series with grit and emotional depth, while the audiobook — expertly narrated by Ron McLarty and Orlagh Cassidy — hits a perfect rhythm for fans of cerebral, character-driven thrillers.

Samantha Blair has spent her life tormented by psychic visions, violent flashes that crash into her mind without warning, leaving her shaken and terrified. But when one of these waking nightmares reveals a murder in chilling, visceral detail, she risks everything to bring the truth to the police. Detective Brandt Sutherland, skeptical but intrigued, soon learns that Sam's gift is as real as it is harrowing. Tuesday's Child blends romantic suspense with a gripping psychic-mystery hook, crafting a heroine whose courage burns through the darkness of her visions. Perfect for readers who want their thrills tangled with heart and high stakes.

August Chase isn't just a private eye … he's a narcoleptic investigator who can step directly into the crimes he's solving. Each time sleep claims him, his dreams reconstruct the scene through the victim's eyes, turning slumber into an intentional act of detection. In Dream State, a missing person case draws him into a world far stranger and deadlier than expected. Hinckley marries noir grit with surreal dream imagery, creating an atmosphere both hypnotic and hard-edged. The audiobook's pacing and style are pitch-perfect for fans of unconventional sleuths and supernatural-noir blends.

A cheeky, genre-bending mystery, The Misadventure of the Psychic Detective follows Ethan Bell, a British psychic with a sarcastic streak and a talent for finding trouble. When a séance goes sideways, Ethan stumbles into a bizarre murder mystery full of ghosts, oddball suspects and more twists than a Victorian penny dreadful. Stadon's writing is sharp and witty and the audiobook brings Ethan's dry humor and chaotic charm to life. It's equal parts parody and homage, perfect for listeners who enjoy their supernatural sleuthing with a heavy dose of irreverent fun.

Mary Bergen has psychic visions that help the police track down brutal killers, but her gift comes from trauma. When she begins having disturbing visions of murders that haven't happened yet, Mary is forced to confront her past, her darkest fears and a deadly truth that's closing in fast. The Vision is classic Koontz: fast-paced, eerie and emotionally charged. The audiobook builds a tense atmosphere as the line between premonition and reality begins to blur. If you're drawn to dark psychological suspense with supernatural elements and a strong female lead, this one should be on your list.

Willa is a small-town psychic who sees violent messages in bones — literal messages etched into remains. When a child's remains are found with a chilling message that only she can interpret, Willa is dragged into a case that exposes secrets buried deep in her community. Message in the Bones is the first in a paranormal crime series that blends rural mystery with chilling clairvoyance. Merriman paints a vivid picture of trauma, intuition and personal strength, while the narrator brings Willa's voice to life with empathy and urgency. This series is ideal for fans of slower-burn mysteries with haunting, human stakes.

Monique Snyman's mind is a confusing bedlam of glitter and death, where candy-coated gore is found in abundance and homicidal unicorns thrive. Sorting out the mess in her head is particularly irksome before she's ingested a specific amount of coffee, which is equal to half the recommended intake of water for humans per day. When she's not playing referee to her imaginary friends or trying to overdose on caffeine, she's doing something with words—be it writing, reading, or editing.

Monique Snyman lives in Pretoria, South Africa, with her husband, daughter, and an adorable Chihuahua. She's the author of the Bram Stoker Award® nominated novels, The Night Weaver and The Bone Carver, and the South African horror series, Dark Country . Visit moniquesnyman.com to find out more!

Title: If you call the Psychic Reading number in Grand Island, you'll reach a woman in Lincoln
Description:
And it could have massive implications for Mars' volcanic past. 

If you dial the Psychic Reading number posted at the intersection of Webb Road and 13th Avenue, you will reach a woman in Lincoln.

Honey Miller is the person who operates Psychic Readings, which has offices in Lincoln and Grand Island.

She's had the office at the high-traffic Grand Island intersection for 10 or 15 years. Her location is at 115 in the Executive Suites strip mall, where the most prominent business is a State Farm office.

Psychic readings by Honey is located at 1233 N. Webb Road in Grand Island.

At her Lincoln office, she does more readings in person than over the phone.

Miller has been doing readings for a long time.

“I'm a third-generation psychic. This is the only thing I've ever done. I've never had any other kind of job,” she said.

Why should people call her?

“I don't like tooting my own horn,” she said. “I'm not that kind of person. But people do say my readings are accurate, and they enjoy being around me, and they enjoy my service.”

Many call her because they're “going through a hard time,” she said. They may have worries about a lot of things.

“And they need something to help them. They need a little clarity, a little guidance,” she said.

“Because some people don't have support, and even if they do have support, there's things that they don't feel comfortable telling just anybody about,” she said.

Psychic readings by Honey is located at 1233 N. Webb Road in Grand Island.

Many people want “to know how a certain situation's going to go. I do my best to help them with that.”

Many tell her they feel much better when they leave, she said. They feel their questions have been answered.

“They tell me that I'm kind, that it's like a pleasure to either talk to me or see me.”

Seeing her, they say, is like going to a friend.

All of her readings are private and confidential. She takes what she does very seriously, she says.

In addition to her own ability, Miller uses tarot cards and does palm readings. Crystal and crystal ball readings are also part of her arsenal. She does not do astrology.

Miller uses her Grand Island office only occasionally.

“I used to come there all the time. But since COVID, not as much.” She does plan to visit the Grand Island office more often.

She speaks fondly of the Grand Island office. “I like it there. The place has got a good energy.”

Psychic readings by Honey is located at 1233 N. Webb Road in Grand Island in the Executive Suites.

She knows that some people regard psychic reading as bunk.

How does she react to that?

“I'm going to be honest. I'm pretty tough-skinned,” she said.

Many people who contact her are skeptics. “But they don't leave skeptics.”

How long does a session last?

“It really depends on what reading the person chooses, because I have a lot of readings.”

How much does a psychic reading cost?

Sometimes Miller runs a special. “I'm not running the special right now, but my readings typically start at $15.”

The sign on her Grand Island door invites people to make an appointment. Her phone number is 308-850-8939.

Title: Joe Rogan doubles down on conspiracy theory over Donald Trump shooting incident
Description:
After initially cracking jokes about existing "in the Matrix" following the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump, podcast host Joe Rogan later cautioned his audience that "conspiracies are real" while diving deeper into the shocking incident.

Rogan expressed disbelief at the glaring failures by the U.S. Secret Service that allowed Trump to be wounded in the ear and suggested there might be hidden elements to the story. Trump was targeted during a rally last summer in Butler, Pennsylvania, with the gunman later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks.

The attacker was eliminated by the Secret Service after his botched assassination bid, having opened fire with a rifle from a neighboring rooftop, though it has since emerged that multiple rally attendees alerted officials about Crooks' location after spotting him with a weapon. It comes after a bizarre close-up photo of Trump's ear caused a wave of new conspiracies one year after the shooting.

The FBI has been investigating Crooks and the July 13 events, while the Secret Service claimed in the aftermath it was conducting an internal examination. The episode has sparked numerous conspiracy theories, and Rogan confessed on his "Joe Rogan Experience" podcast that the pieces don't fit together perfectly.

"The more you read about it, the more you're, like, 'What is going on?'" Rogan told comedian Sam Morril, who appeared as a guest on the program. "They knew that there was a suspicious person 10 minutes before Trump went on stage; they still let him go on stage.

"They saw him on the ------- roof and they didn't engage. They saw him on the roof with a rifle. They wouldn't put Secret Service agents on the roof because they said there was a slope to the roof, and it would be dangerous."

Morril then declared: "It's more dangerous if the ex-president gets shot, which he did." Rogan responded by saying: "Dude, it's so crazy, and the fact that they had such poor security guarding him. Like, they did such a terrible job."

Rogan then issued a warning by stating he wasn't suggesting an alternative theory but reminded his audience that he doesn't always trust the official government account. "I'm not accusing anybody of anything - just want to be real clear - but they have organized assassinations before," Rogan added. "And when they organize assassinations, it looks just like that.

"And when they organize assassinations, one of the things they like to do is have some ------- loser kill the president and then they kill the ------- loser, and that's a wrap. This kid kind of, like, stops all the leads."

Rogan couldn't resist questioning why the authorities didn't stop Crooks, and even pondered the possibility of him being recruited. "If you're Secret Service, you see someone with a range finder walking 150 yards from where the president is, you tackle that ------- guy. You don't let that guy get on a ladder," Rogan stated.

"If I was some shadowy intelligence agency that did these, you know, undercover operations that are a little sketchy, I'd find kids like [the shooter]. That's your moneymaker. That's how you do it. If you've got a plan and you want to do something, you get some guy that's basically got nothing going on in life and then you know you mentor him, become friends with him.

"Maybe that guy's dad is an alcoholic who beats [him]. You know, maybe his mom is a ------- junkie. Who knows? Maybe his life is terrible, and you can provide mentorship and you can provide, you know, just camaraderie. Something [to make the potential shooter say], 'Wow, I wish I was a secret agent.' And then you tell this guy, you tell this kid, 'Hey, you could help America. We can work you into the program. You could be one of us.'".

Rogan's chat with Morril then shifted to another infamous presidential assassination, after John F. Kennedy was shot and killed back in 1963.

The Kennedy story is one of the most notorious conspiracy topics in U.S. history, and Rogan didn't hold back his thoughts on the matter.

"Listen, conspiracies are real," Rogan declared. "I mean, whatever the ---- happened in Dallas, Texas, in 1963, it's not what they tell you. That's one thing; 100 percent you're going to be sure. There is no objective journalism with no slant."

It comes after Rogan previously turned on Trump as a scandal engulfed his presidency.

Title: $50,000 reward: do you know who killed Veronica Perotti?
Description:
The unsolved murder of 19-year-old Veronica Perotti continues to haunt her family and the community. Perotti was brutally beaten to death in her apartment on West Second Avenue on June 28, 1984.

Perotti, fondly known as “Roni” by her family, was a nursing student from Marin County. She was taking summer classes and preparing for her sophomore year when her life was tragically cut short.

Her mother, Jan Miller, became an advocate for other crime victims by helping to establish “Citizens Against Homicide.” Miller has tirelessly sought information about her daughter's murder, including posting billboards offering a $50,000 reward.

Title: Are We Ready for First Contact?
Description:
Hello Evreyone,
    


      From a purely scientific perspective, and based on astronomical evidence, I believe that intelligent life beyond Earth is not a product of science fiction, but a strong possibility supported by the facts of the universe itself. We live in a cosmos containing hundreds of billions of galaxies, each with hundreds of billions of stars, many accompanied by planets and regions that could potentially support life. Given such vastness, the probability that we are the only intelligent beings in existence is extremely small.
    


      Yet I have an unshakable curiosity: if the day comes when visitors from other worlds knock on Earth's door, will we truly be ready to welcome them?
    


      We humans still face difficulties in coexistence in some parts of our world, as conflicts continue to divide certain regions. So how would we interact with beings fundamentally different from us in biology, communication methods, social systems—and perhaps even in logic and reasoning?
    


      This raises critical questions: Who would establish the "Coexistence Agreement"?
    


      Would such an agreement be shaped by the great powers, or by the alien visitors themselves?
    


      And would the other party even agree to it, or instead impose its own terms?
    


      What if these beings possessed moral values or technologies far beyond our own?
    


      This discussion is not for random speculation, but for exchanging ideas, exploring possible scenarios, and examining scientific projections for such an encounter—whether we view it as a bridge to unprecedented cosmic cooperation, or as the start of existential challenges that could reshape the course of human civilization.
    

Anyone can view, post, and comment to this community

Title: Zelensky refuses to cede Donbas, says doing so would give Putin ‘springboard' for future offensives
Description:
Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky vowed on Tuesday not to give eastern Ukrainian land to Russia, saying that abandoning the Donbas region would open the door for Russian President Vladimir Putin to “start a third war” in Ukraine.
    


            Zelensky's warning comes ahead of Putin's meeting with US President Donald Trump in Alaska on Friday, where the Russian president is expected to demand Ukrainian land as part of a peace deal.
    


            While there is confusion over Putin's reported conditions for a ceasefire, most versions stress that the Russian president will demand that Ukrainian forces withdraw from all parts of Ukraine's Donbas, which includes parts of the Donetsk region it still holds.
    


            “For the Russians, Donbas is a springboard for a future new offensive. If we leave Donbas of our own accord or under pressure, we will start a third war,” Zelensky said in a meeting with journalists. Russia illegally annexed the Crimean peninsula in 2014, and went on to launch its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.
    


            “I am not going to surrender my country because I have no right to do so,” he added. “If we leave Donbas today, our fortifications, our terrain, the heights we control, we will clearly open a bridgehead for the preparation of a Russian offensive.”
    


Russian troops pierce Ukraine's patchy defenses in Donetsk, days before Trump-Putin summit



            Zelensky and Ukrainian military officials have warned that Russia is building up troops for a new offensive, ready to launch by September.
    


            “I haven't heard anything — not a single proposal that would guarantee that a new war won't start tomorrow and that Putin won't try to occupy at least Dnipro, Zaporizhzhia and Kharkiv,” the Ukrainian president told reporters.
    


            “The exchange of territories is a very complex issue that cannot be separated from security guarantees for Ukraine, for our sovereign state and our people,” Zelensky added, noting that the European Union's involvement in peace talks is also crucial because “no one except Europe is giving us security guarantees.”
    


            A conversation between the US, Ukraine and “all of Europe” will take place on Wednesday, according to the Ukrainian president.
    


            Trump has signaled Zelensky would not participate in Friday's summit, though the US president previewed his plans to phone Kyiv immediately after the meeting, along with other European leaders, to brief them.
    


Panic in eastern Ukraine as Trump entertains idea of giving parts of it to Russia



Trump said his goal is ultimately to get Putin and Zelensky in the same room to hash out their differences, and surmised only they would be able to find a way to end the war with some “land swapping” between them.
    


            “I'm not going to make a deal,” Trump said. “It's not up to me to make a deal. I think a deal should be made for both.”
    


            The White House on Tuesday characterized the upcoming meeting between Trump and Putin in Anchorage as a “listening exercise.”
    


            “Only one party that's involved in this war is going to be present, and so this is for the president to go and to get, again, a more firm and better understanding of how we can hopefully bring this war to an end,” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters.
    


            Asked by CNN's Kaitlan Collins whether the two presidents would meet one-on-one, Leavitt said that is “part of the plan.”
    


            Zelensky also gave further details on Tuesday about the diplomatic talks that have been taking place behind the scenes, as well as his take on the outcome of US special envoy Steve Witkoff's meeting with Putin.
    


            “Witkoff said that there should be territorial concessions on both sides. That's how it sounded. And that Putin probably wants us to leave Donbas. So it didn't sound like America wants us to leave,” Zelensky said. “I do not believe that Putin's proposal is Trump's proposal. I believe that Trump represents the United States of America. He acts as a mediator, he is in the middle – not on Russia's side.”
    


  CNN's Betsy Klein and Kevin Liptak contributed to this report.

Title: AI search firm Perplexity makes $34.5 billion surprise bid for Google Chrome
Description:
Markets 




Hot Stocks 




Fear & Greed Index 





            Latest Market News 





            Hot Stocks 





            Artificial intelligence search company Perplexity has made an unsolicited, $34.5 billion offer to purchase Google's Chrome browser, a surprise move by a Google Search challenger that's looking to upend how people find information online.
    


            Perplexity spokesperson Jesse Dwyer confirmed to CNN the details of the offer, which The Wall Street Journal first reported.
    


            The bid comes as Google awaits a court's decision after a landmark ruling last year found that the internet giant had violated US antitrust law with its search business. The US Justice Department has proposed as a remedy that Google sell its Chrome browser.
    


            Google has promised to appeal the ruling and called the idea of spinning off Chrome an “unprecedented proposal” that it says would harm consumers and security. Google declined to provide a comment to CNN regarding Perplexity's bid.
    


            Perplexity's offer — while likely a long shot, given Google's resistance to a forced sale of Chrome — marks the latest example of how new firms are taking on tech's biggest players to reshape the internet in the AI era.
    


            Perplexity is a nearly three-year-old startup whose search tool uses AI models to parse web content and curate answers. Answers are usually posted as a summary, although Perplexity does provide links to its sources. It launched an AI search engine that competes with Google's dominant offering in December 2022.
    


AI search firm Perplexity makes $34.5 billion surprise bid for Google Chrome



            Perplexity launched its own AI-powered web browser called Comet in July. The company is pitching it as a more personalized browser that connects the dots between a user's calendars, browsing tabs, social channels and more. OpenAI is also said to be developing a web browser, according to Reuters, in yet another signal that AI companies are looking to play a bigger role in how people use the web.
    


            Perplexity said it would maintain users' current browsing preferences, including Google as the default search engine, if it were to buy Chrome, Dwyer told CNN.
    


            It would also commit to “continued available and support” for Chrome for 100 months and investing $3 billion in Chromium over the next 24 months, according to Dwyer. Chromium is Google's open-source underlying technology that other tech companies – including Microsoft and Perplexity – can use to build their own browsers.
    


            Perplexity made the offer because it “believes in the open web,” Dwyer said.
    


            Perplexity was most recently valued at $18 billion following a $100 million funding round, Bloomberg said in a report last month, citing a person familiar with the matter. The company did not comment on the report.
    


            That makes Perplexity's offer for Chrome worth nearly double its own valuation. Google, meanwhile, is worth nearly $2.5 trillion; shares of the company (GOOGL) rose around 1% on Tuesday. The Wall Street Journal reported that several investors have agreed to back the purchase, including large venture capital firms.
    


            “This is a smart and opportunistic move by Perplexity given the case against Google and regulatory scrutiny,” Wedbush tech analyst Dan Ives told CNN, adding that he estimates Chrome is worth at least $50 billion. “This is all a game of high stakes poker and Perplexity made a good move.”
    


            Google Chrome isn't the only high profile acquisition target that Perplexity has pursued. The company said earlier this year it was making a bid to buy TikTok, after a law was passed last year requiring the social media app's parent company, ByteDance, to sell it to a non-China-based company or face a ban in the United States.
    


            Perplexity has also reportedly been eyeballed by bigger tech players — both Meta and Apple have had discussions about buying the AI search firm, according to reports from Bloomberg and The Information, although it's not clear the talks will go anywhere.
    


This story has been updated with additional developments and context.

Title: EU staff push back against Gaza policy
Description:
European Union staff are in a standoff with the European Commission over their right to protest its stance on Israel, accusing the bloc of breaching their moral and legal obligations, Politico has reported.

The civil servants say the EU's position on the Gaza war puts them in violation of European and international law, the outlet cited unnamed officials from the bloc as saying on Tuesday.

One official said “complicity” has been imposed on employees, violating their “moral and legal obligations, suppressed conscientious resistance and delayed meaningful action.” 

Since late July, around 1,500 officials have reportedly signed an open letter warning of worsening humanitarian conditions in Gaza and a surge in starvation-related deaths unless more aid is allowed. Some have considered picketing, although the labor unions remain divided and the legal implications are unclear. 

An internal group has alleged “intimidation” tactics against protesters, including the removal of staff, forced deletion of videos, and non-renewal of contracts. 

A Commission spokesperson said EU foreign policy is set by national governments and that civil servants must remain neutral, adding that the workplace is not a venue for activism. 

Rights groups have accused the bloc of indirectly backing Israel's war by maintaining arms exports, preferential trade, and joint research projects – despite its own diplomats finding Israel in breach of human rights clauses.

Humanitarian agencies say that from early March to May, aid deliveries to Gaza were completely blocked off. The UN has reported that convoys continue to face obstruction and looting, warning by late July of “mounting evidence” of famine, with images of severely malnourished children circulating worldwide.

Last week, West Jerusalem approved a plan to seize Gaza City, with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insisting it was the only way to secure the release of Hamas-held hostages and demilitarize the enclave. His remarks have resulted in widespread criticism and domestic protests.

Around 50 hostages remain unaccounted for in Gaza, with only about 20 believed to be alive. Hamas attacked Israel in October 2023, killing some 1,200 people and abducting 251 more. Since then, more than 60,000 Palestinians have been killed in West Jerusalem's military campaign, according to Gaza's Health Ministry.

Title: Turkey ready to host summit on Ukraine — Erdogan
Description:
ISTANBUL, August 12. /TASS/. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has told Vladimir Zelensky that his country is ready to host a summit on Ukraine, the Turkish president's administration said after the two held a phone call.

"Turkey is ready to host a leaders' summit. The establishment of working groups on military, humanitarian, and political issues will open up a path to a summit meeting," Erdogan was quoted as saying.

"President Erdogan held a phone call with Vladimir Zelensky at the Ukrainian side's request. He noted that the progress that has been reached during the direct Ukraine-Russia talks in Istanbul is crucially important and expressed hope that the next rounds of talks will yield significant results toward a ceasefire and a lasting peace," Erdogan's office said.

The Turkish leader all voiced support for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

Istanbul hosted the third round of direct Russian-Ukrainian talks on July 23. During the 40-minute talks that were preceded by a tete-a-tete meeting between the delegation heads, Vladimir Medinsky of Russia and Rustem Umerov of Ukraine, the sides discussed their positions laid down in their memorandums.

The meeting yielded an agreement to exchange not only military but also civilians. Russia proposed to set up three working groups to address political, military, and humanitarian issues. Apart from that, Moscow offered Kiev to transfer 3,000 more bodies of Ukrainian troops and suggested that the practice of short humanitarian pauses be resumed along the frontline to collect the wounded and bodies of those killed.

According to Medinsky, a decision on the fourth round of talks will be made after the third round's agreements are implemented.

Title: First Thing: Trump slammed for ‘unjustified power grab' as he seizes control of DC police and deploys national guard
Description:
Trump forwarded a false narrative around DC crime stats to justify the move. Plus, funeral held in Gaza for five journalists killed by Israeli attack

Good morning.

Donald Trump has ordered the national guard to Washington DC and seized control of the city's police force, describing a “lawless” city in ways that are sharply at odds with official crime statistics.

The president's move was swiftly condemned as a “disgusting, dangerous and derogatory” assault on the political independence of a racially diverse city. The federal takeover is expected to be in effect for 30 days, the White House confirmed to the Guardian.

Speaking at a White House press conference on Monday, Trump alleged DC was “one of the most dangerous cities anywhere in the world”, even though violent crime is at a 30-year low.

What do the crime figures tell us? That Trump is spreading a false narrative about DC crime – just as he did with LA. Violent crime in DC is at a 30-year low. In January, the Metropolitan police department and US attorney's office released a report indicating that total violent crime in DC in 2024 was down 35% from the previous year, marking the lowest rate in over 30 years.

How are Democrats responding? Hakeem Jeffries, the Democratic minority leader in the House, described Trump as a “wannabe king” and said: “We stand with the residents of the District of Columbia and reject this unjustified power grab as illegitimate.”

The death of the prominent Al Jazeera journalist Anas al-Sharif, killed along with four colleagues in an Israeli airstrike on Sunday, prompted condemnation from around the world, as hundreds of mourners carried their bodies through the streets of Gaza City.

Sharif, one of Al Jazeera's most recognisable faces in Gaza, was killed while inside a tent for journalists outside al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City on Sunday night. Seven people were killed in the attack, including the Al Jazeera correspondent Mohammed Qreiqeh and the camera operators Ibrahim Zaher, Mohammed Noufal and Moamen Aliwa, according to the Qatar-based broadcaster.

How deadly has the war been for journalists? Before Sunday's airstrike, the Committee to Protect Journalists recorded at least 186 journalists and media workers killed in Gaza, the West Bank, Israel and Lebanon since the war began, making it the deadliest period for journalists since it began gathering data in 1992. The CPJ accuses Israel of directly targeting and killing 20 journalists and media workers. Any deliberate attack on a civilian could constitute a war crime, experts say. Israel, which has refused to let international media into Gaza, denies the accusation.

Donald Trump has announced he is nominating EJ Antoni, the chief economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation, as the next commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The nomination comes after Trump fired the BLS commissioner, Erika McEntarfer, earlier this month following the release of a weak jobs report.

Trump, without evidence, alleged McEntarfer “faked” employment numbers in the run-up to the 2024 election to boost Kamala Harris's chances and said that the recent data was “rigged” to make Trump and Republicans look bad.

What happens next? The Senate will have to confirm Antoni's nomination to lead the BLS, an independent agency under the labor department. Experts fear Trump's interventions will undermine the credibility of the agency's economic data, long seen as a gold standard.

Donald Trump said he and Vladimir Putin would discuss “land swapping” when they meet on Friday in Alaska for a summit on the Ukraine war, and expressed frustration with Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Meanwhile, Trump again delayed implementing sweeping tariffs on China, announcing another 90-day pause hours before the last agreement expired.

An explosion at a US Steel plant in Pennsylvania killed two people and injured at least 10 on Monday. “It felt like thunder,” said one worker near the scene.

Spain's central government has ordered officials in a Spanish town to scrap a ban on religious gatherings in public sports centers, describing it as a “discriminatory” measure mainly affecting Muslims.

Villagers whose farms in Vietnam will be bulldozed to make way for a $1.5bn golf resort backed by the Trump family have reportedly been offered rice provisions and cash compensation of as little as $12 for a square meter of land by state authorities. Thousands of villagers will be offered compensation based on land size and location, according to a report by Reuters.

Anas al-Sharif, an Al Jazeera reporter, was killed by an Israeli airstrike on Sunday night. Before his killing, he prepared a message for his family, and calling for the world not to forget Gaza. “I have lived through pain in all its details, tasted suffering and loss many times, yet I never once hesitated to convey the truth as it is, without distortion or falsification,” he writes.

Nurdles: they're buoyant, the size of a lentil and almost impossible to recover. Millions of these tiny plastic pellets are being washed up on the coast of Kerala in India in the latest in a series of global spills – with sea creatures thinking they're eggs – as plastic treaty talks continue in Geneva until Thursday.

Ventriloquism is back in vogue on stage and online. Its new hip practitioners explain why their vocal tricks and errant dummies are wowing audiences again. “It is very stripped back. That's why it feels fresh,” one ventriloquist says.

First Thing is delivered to thousands of inboxes every weekday. If you're not already signed up, subscribe now.
